Horizontal guidelines between lines, but almost no interlineation. The text maintains left and right margins (with guideline indicating an outer right margin), with words broken across lines or abbreviated to maintain the margins. Interpuncts mark the ends of lines 2 and 3.
Tall narrow letters with pronounced serifs and curved horizontal feet to vertical strokes.

3Tyche · et · Herm(es) · fe(cerunt) ·
Inscription recording construction of a sphaeristrium by a father and son
Text fills the face, with traces of a larger line above; surviving line 1 is larger than the lines below.
Elegant tall and somewhat narrow v-cut letters with serifs. O is large, broad, and somewhat irregular in shape. R has curved and extended foot, P is open. G has straight foot.
Photo J.Prag, 2022-05-23, courtesy Museo Archeologico Regionale Antonino Salinas

use of serifs and interpuncts, with some instances of tall and small letters, and ligatures.
later first or second century CE

Fragment of an inscription referencing one of the emperors styled Marcus Aurelius
Tall and very narrow letters, fairly crudely carved, with AV in ligature.
The reference could be to one of several emperors from Marcus Aurelius (161 CE) onwards, although a third century date is more likely given the form of the letters.
Castelli, 1762, Le antiche iscrizioni di Palermo

The text maintains a justified left margin, but uneven right margin, with words regularly broken across the line-end, and no attempt to make the end of the text symmetrical or to match the content to the line-length / layout, as opposed to simply a consistent filling of the face until the text is complete.
Tall, relatively narrow letters, with short horizontal strokes often curving upwards (especially on T).

Funerary altar for Quintus Caecilius Pulcher

The visible text is set out over four lines, with the text poorly spaced and cramped against the right margin in lines 2-4. Theoretically a first line above the visible lines is possible, given the space, but the damage to the top part of the face has removed any possible traces.
Roman imperial, first or earlier second century CE

Funerary epitaph for Cn. Caninius Anicetus
Text is centred, with almost a full blank line between the name of the deceased and the phrase recording the dedicant.
Deeply cut, compact letters, with some serifs and some curved elements; relatively wide module.

Dedication to Isis and Serapis by Caius Ennius Secundus
Latin text over three lines, intended to be centred on the stone, but the right margin is poorly controlled and the text runs up against the edge.
Deeply incised letters (reflecting the need for exaggerated depth for visibility on this stone?) with serifs, and angular or comma-shaped interpuncts.
Manganaro, 1961, Ricerche di epigrafia siceliota. I. Per la storia del culto delle divinita orientali in Sicilia
Muscolino, 2014, San Pancrazio e il Falcone. culti antichi e recenti da Taormina a Naxos. I.
dedication to isis and serapis by caius ennius secundus

The epigraphic field, of three lines of Latin letters, decreasing in size, is approximately centred on the plaque, with an upper margin of 4.5cm, a lower margin of 1.8cm, left margin of 2.5 cm and right margin of 2 cm.

The letters are v-cut in a tall and narrow module, with triangular serifs. The letters are regularly spaced, with the size / spacing decreasing towards the right and from line 1 to line 3. A has a cross bar descending to the left; M has four full length strokes, all off vertical. Interpuncts in the form of ivy-leaf (somewhat various in form) at the end of each line; plainer interpuncts between words in line 3.

Epitaph for Domitius Himeraeus, his sister Domitia and his wife Alfia Zotica
Three lines of roughly equal and centred latin letters filling the face of the stone, words separated by lightly carved interpuncts.
Simply cut reasonably regular letters, with one instance of ligature and an extended T in line 2.
Bivona suggests that the onomastics (presence of tribal, use of Aulus and lack of cognomen in the sister's name) imply a date in the first half of the C1 CE
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2021-09-27

The text occupies two lines with interpuncts visible at the end of line 1 and between words in line 2. It is possible that the text continued below, or to the right, on another block, but it is complete in itself
The letters are archaic in form, in particular the square, open P; the form of the R; the off-vertical N, and the rigid S.

Bilingual sign advertising engraving of inscriptions

The text fills the face of the plaque, divided vertically by a deeply incised line into two unequal halves, with a column of Greek on the left (wider) and Latin on the right). Each column is approximately centred, and consists of seven lines of text, with the first two lines notably larger than the following five.
Greek text includes lunate sigma and epsilon; extended apex to delta and alpha. Latin text is is regular with serifs, open P, closed R. There are no word dividers or punctuation in either text.

Augustan or Julio-Claudian,
                                by the letter forms; also, archaic spelling of some of the Latin, with other Sicilian
                                parallels, rules out much later date (so Wilson 1990); Manni Piraino thinks later 2nd century CE
